chapter.sect1:
Launching Instances &instances; &inst-launch-params;
For details, refer to .
For SSH access to an instance, you usually need to provide a keypair at launch time. In case an image uses a static &rootuser; password or a static key set (neither is recommended), you do not need to provide a keypair on start of the instance.
Creating or Importing Keys
Use the nova keypair-add command to generate a new keypair, or to upload an existing public key.
To generate a new keypair, execute the following commands: nova keypair-add KEY_NAME > MY_KEY.pem chmod 600 MY_KEY.pem
The first command generates a new keypair named KEY_NAME, writing the private key to the file MY_KEY.pem and registering the public key at the Nova database. The second command changes the permissions of the file MY_KEY.pem so that only you can read and write to it.
If you already have generated a keypair, with the public key located at ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub, you can upload the public key with the following command: nova keypair-add --pub_key ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub KEY_NAME
The command registers the public key at the Nova database and names the keypair KEY_NAME.
Check if the uploaded keypair appears in the list of availabe keypairs: nova keypair-list
Before you can launch an instance, you need to look up a few parameters, for example, which images, flavors, and security groups are available.
Launching an Instance
On a shell, source the &ostack; RC file. For details, refer to .
Look up the available flavors and memorize the ID of the flavor that you want to use for your instance: nova flavor-list
Look up the available images and memorize the ID of the image that you want to boot your instance from: nova image-list
Look up the available security groups: nova secgroup-list
If you did not create any specific security groups, you can only assign the instance to the default security group.

nova boot --flavor FLAVOR_ID --imageIMAGE_ID --key_name KEY_NAME --security_group NAME_OF_SEC_GROUP
After you have launched an instance, switch to the Instances & Volumes category to view the Instance Name, its (private or public) IP address, its Size, its Status, Task, and Power State.
&cloud; ‐—List of Launched Instances
If you did not provide a keypair on start and did not touch security groups or rules so far, by default the instance can only be accessed from inside the cloud via VNC at this point. Even pinging the instance is not possible. To change this, proceed with .

Configuring Access to the Instances &inst-access-params;
Creating or Importing Keys &keypairs;
In case an image uses a static &rootuser; password or a static key set (neither is recommended), you do not need to provide a keypair on start of the instance.
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the selected project.
To import a keypair that you have generated with an external tool:
Click Import Keypair.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the keypair and copy the public key into the respective input field.
Confirm your choice.
To create a new keypair:
Click Create Keypair.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the keypair and confirm your choice.
&ostack; generates a keypair and provides the private key for download as a *.pem file.
Save the *.pem file locally and change its permissions so that only you can read and write to the file: chmod 600 MY_PRIV_KEY.pem
The public key of the keypair is registered at the Nova database. The ‐ lists the keypair in the Access & Security category as shown in .
&cloud; ‐—Keypairs
Configuring Security Groups and Rules &security;
Security Groups &sec-groups;
Creating Or Deleting Security Groups
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the selected project.
To create a new security group:
Click Create Security Group.
In the window that opens, enter a Name and Description for the group and confirm your changes.
To delete one or multiple security groups:
Activate the check boxes in front of the groups that you want to delete.
Click Delete Security Groups and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
Deleting Security Groups
The default security group for a project cannot be deleted.
In case another group cannot be deleted, it is still assigned to a running instance.
Security Group Rules &sec-rules;
&sec-rules-params;
&security-default;
Configuring Security Group Rules
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the selected project.
Select the security group to modify and click Edit Rules. The window that appears shows which rules have already been configured.
To allow SSH access to the instances:
Set IP Protocol to TCP.
Enter the value 22 in both From Port and To Port.
To allow access from all IP addresses (specified as IP subnet in CIDR notation as 0.0.0.0/0), leave the other fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, select the desired security group from the CIDR drop-down list.
Confirm your changes to add the rule.
To allow pinging the instances:
Set IP Protocol to ICMP.
Enter the value -1 in both From Port and To Port. This allows access to all codes and all types of ICMP traffic, respectively.
To allow access from all IP addresses (0.0.0.0/0), leave the other fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only members of other security groups to ping instances. In that case, select the desired security group from the CIDR drop-down list.
Confirm your changes to add the rule.
To allow access via UDP port (for example, for an DNS server running on a VM):
Set IP Protocol to UDP.
Enter the value 53 in both From Port and To Port.
To allow access from all IP addresses (0.0.0.0/0), leave the other fields unchanged.
Alternatively, allow only IP addresses from other security groups to access the specified port. In that case, select the desired security group from the CIDR drop-down list.
Confirm your changes to add the rule.
&cloud; ‐—Adding Security Rules
Managing IP Addresses &ip-addr;
&ip-allocate;
Allocating Floating (Public) IPs to a Project
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows a list of Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the current project.
To allocate a floating IP address to the current project:
Click Allocate IP to Project.
In the window that opens, select a Pool out of which to take the IP address.
Click Allocate IP.
The ‐ shows the allocated IP addresses in the Access & Security category. The first IP shown for an instance is the private IP address, the second one is the floating IP address.
To release one or multiple floating IP addresses from a project:
Activate the check boxes in front of the IP addresses that you want to release.
Click Release Floating IPs. The IP addresses are put back into the pool of IP addresses that are available for all projects. If an IP address is currently assigned to a running instance, it will automatically be dissociated from the instance.
Assigning Floating (Public) IP Addresses to Instances &ip-assign;
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Access & Security category. The ‐ shows a list of Floating IPs, Security Groups, and Keypairs for the current project.
Select an IP address and click Associate IP.
In the window that opens, select the Instance to associate the IP with and confirm your choice.
In the Access & Security category, the list of Floating IPs shows the ID of the instance with which the IP has been associated. The instance is now publicly available under the respective floating IPs address (provided you have also configured the security group rules for the instance accordingly). For details, refer to .

sect1.title: Managing Instances
sect1.para: The following are typical tasks for managing instances:

listitem.para: Creating instance snapshots to preserve a certain disk state of an instance
Using instance snapshots as base for new images

step.para: If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Select the instance and from the Actions drop-down list, select View Log.
Alternatively, click the instance's name and switch to the Log tab that opens.
The ‐ shows the output of the instance's serial console. To make use of this feature, the respective image must have set the serial console correctly in &grub;.

sect1.sect2:
Accessing Instances from Remote
The ‐'s built-in VNC client allows you to access instances at any time.
Accessing an Instance via VNC
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the instance to access and from the Actions drop-down list, select VNC Console.
Alternatively, click the instance's name and switch to the VNC tab that opens.
To display a larger VNC screen, use the link Click here to show only VNC.
To leave the large VNC screen, use the back button of the browser.
&ssh-req;

Using Instance Snapshots &inst-snap; taroth 2012-08-21: DEVs, if I got it right, ephemeral disks are generally excluded from the snapshots?
Creating Instance Snapshots
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the instance of which to create a snapshot. From the Actions drop-down list, select Snapshot.
In the window that opens, enter a name for the snapshot and confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the new Instance Snapshot in the Images & Snapshot category.
To launch a new instance from the snapshot, select the snapshot and click Launch. Proceed with launching an instance as described in .
Basing an Image on a Snapshot
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Images & Snapshots category.
Select the snapshot and from the Actions drop-down list, select Edit.
In the window that opens, enter the image properties. For more information, refer to .
Click Update Image.
‐ shows the newly created image in the list of images in the Images & Snapshot category. If you delete the snapshot, upon which the image is based, the image will be deleted as well. If you delete the image, the snapshot upon which it is based, will be deleted as well.

sect2.title: Tracking Usage
sect2.para: Use the ‐'s Overview category to track usage of instances per project. It allows you to track costs per month by showing metrics like number of VCPUs, disks, RAM and uptime of all your instances.

If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab. Select a month and click Submit to query the instance usage for that month. The ‐ also allows to download a CVS summary.

chapter.sect1:
Managing Volumes &volumes;
Creating or Deleting Volumes
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
To create a volume:
Click Create Volume.
In the window that opens, enter a name to assign to a volume, a description (optional), and define the size in GB.
Confirm your changes.
The ‐ shows the volume in the Instances & Volumes category.
To delete one or multiple volumes:
Activate the check boxes in front of the volumes that you want to delete.
Click Delete Volumes and confirm your choice in the pop-up that appears.taroth 2012-08-23: check what happens if the volume is attached to an instance! taroth 2012-08-27: according to bmwiedemann, deleting attached volumes should be refused
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
&vol-attach; View the Status of a volume in the Instances & Volumes category of the ‐: The volume is either available or already In-Use.
Attaching Volumes to Instances
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the volume to add to an instance and click Edit Attachments.
In the window that opens, select an instance to attach the volume to.
Enter a Device Name under which the volume should be accessible on the virtual machine.
Confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the instance to which the volume has been attached and the volume's device name.
Now you can log in to the instance, mount the disk, format it and use it.
If the instance is running the latest &sls; SP2 Kernel, it is not necessary to reboot the virtual machine to make the device appear. Otherwise load the acpiphp module manually: modprobe acpiphp
To detach a volume from an instance:
Select the volume and click Edit Attachments.
In the window that opens, click Detach Volume and confirm your changes.
A message on the Web page shows if the action has been successful.
Creating Volume Snapshots
Log in to &cloud; ‐.
If you are a member of multiple projects, select a Project from the drop-down list at the top of the tab.
Click the Instances & Volumes category.
Select the volume of which to create a snapshot.
From the Actions drop-down list, select Create Snapshot.
In the window that opens, enter a Snapshot Name and a Description.
Confirm your changes. The ‐ shows the new Volume Snapshot in the Images & Snapshot category.
